title: Thursday, 23nd February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hi! Hello, welcome, good morning, etc.

BE11:06am

And ......... yep, looks okay. That's two days running!

BE11:07am

But let's not jinx it by pointing that out. Don't want to give the technology performance anxiety.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

........So, PM is ill. Might be joining us at some point, but is currently AWOL.

BE11:08am

We can continue regardless, though I've forgotten to find a picture.

BE11:10am

Index wise, nothing much is happening because everything with results is up and everything that's ex div is down.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

(@ROTR: we'd prefer if you didn't use this medium to talk about other media. Thanks.)

BE11:11am

FTSE off 0.1%, 7 points, though EasyJet, Rio, HSBC etc all ex.

BE11:12am

(@ROTR: also, apropos of nothing specific, please be careful typing anything that you might think is legally problematic. We're not here to wear your risk. We don't have enough money to do that.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Feel free to make requests with regards results. Instead, we can start with a bit of knife catching.

undefined
Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 116.60, up 5.3 (+4.76%), High: 116.86, Low: 113.00, Volume: 4.83m
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Investec buying!

BE11:13am

What does it take to be a buyer of Cobham here? First, to believe the company has uncovered all of its major problems and the financial implications (i.e. dividend suspension). Second, a belief that the new management team are able to correct the balance sheet weakness, steady the ship operationally, strengthen the divisional management team and start to rebuild investor confidence. These conditions are moving into place, in our view, and as such we upgrade to Buy.

BE11:14am

You'll remember that Cobham has said that it nearly definitely needs a rights issue.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Which makes buying pre event rather brave.

BE11:15am

(@wayneJ: Apologies. Screenshots to paul.murphy@ft.com if you please. We struggle to offer tech support on the fly.)

BE11:16am

The Buy case: Cobham has many problems. However, in our view, these are rectifiable over the medium term if the business units are managed properly. We recognise this is not a quick fix. Our view is based on historic performance, peer group analysis and industry commentary. If the new management team succeeds, then the company should be able to take advantage of a recovery in its defence end markets as well as a pickup in its commodity-related activities, which should lead to low/mid single-digit revenue growth towards the end of the decade and a recovery of margins towards the mid-teens. This is well above what recent cuts to consensus imply (we forecast a 12.5% margin in FY19E). Cash generation should also improve substantially back to historic levels. Longer term, there is the potential to reposition the portfolio. Cobham is now a recovery stock, in our view.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Investec's case is a £500m equity issue at a c.25% discount, c.26% dilutive to our 2018 EPS.

BE11:17am

The number in the market earlier this week was ....... well, wide.

BE11:17am

£300m to £600m.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's Investec's sensitivity chart.

BE11:18am

undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

So, on Unilever.

BE11:18am

And yesterday's peculiar events.

BE11:19am

Never seen a company put out two RNS statements, neither running to more than a paragraph, without any kind of obvious prompting.

11:19 am
Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,764, down 27.5 (-0.73%), High: 3,789, Low: 3,743, Volume: 1.26m
BE11:20am

Neither was I expecting shares to go above Friday's record-high close .... as in, back when the bid was still on the table.

BE11:20am

(Though they calmed down a bit by the end of session.)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Theory among the sellside is that "review" means "sell food, keep soap."

BE11:22am

Two bits of research. Socgen first, saying buy.

BE11:22am

We have been lukewarm on Unilever as we saw it as a mass market consumer portfolio underweight in premium where most of the growth is. Our main concern was its weak volumes and its positioning between a recovering P&G on one hand and strong local competition on the other. In our view this is now trumped by the consequences of the aborted Kraft Heinz bid and the statement that all options are potentially on the table following ‘last week’s events’, many of which may have been considered taboo in the past. Pandora’s box has been opened and there is no going back A chill wind could blow across European Staples with the sector looking more like US Food where a big consideration is what 3G (and we would include JAB) does next and what level of margin is needed to fend them off. Consider Kraft Heinz’s consensus 2017 EBIT margin of 30% vs Unilever’s 16%.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We think Unilever might consider setting a net debt/EBITDA target (2.5x or 3x?) without being specific about the mix of buybacks vs M&A. In the past Unilever hasn’t been keen on buybacks but this may have changed. We wouldn’t rule out a special dividend either. We also think it can push the ZBB savings higher, perhaps increasing its total savings from €2bn pa from 2018e to €3bn by 2020e. A longer shot but not impossible is Unilever announces a de-merger of Food and HPC, but that’s not our base case as dis-synergies would be an issue and each part would be more not less vulnerable to 3G. Thus it might be wise not to say too much about M&A in April but just get on and do it. At a minimum we think spreads need to be dealt with as we argued in our ‘Sprexit’ note last year (link here). Thinking more blue sky, the four deals which would transform Unilever would be to sell Foods to Kraft- Heinz, divest tea to JAB and buy Edgewell but the truly transformational deal would be Colgate where we still see compelling strategic logic. Short term there is a risk of travel and arrive into April given the pop in the shares, but the close call with 3G fundamentally changes management’s mindset and positive catalysts could extend well beyond April as it remains on the front foot. See page two for our one-page graphic of its options

BE11:24am

And Merrill Lynch, saying sell.

BE11:24am

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Take your pick. We don't know.

undefined
BE11:24am

Okay, so @Scalper makes an interesting observation.

11:24 am
Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 146.83, down 0.425 (-0.29%), High: 148.75, Low: 146.00, Volume: 1.92m
BE11:25am

Lively yesterday, and at a record high.

BE11:25am

Here's a good chart.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(You might need to right click and open new window to make sense of it.)

BE11:25am

BE11:26am

So. White line's Boohoo, which has gone from 25p in June 2015 to nearly 150p today.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

The other lines make clear that's not on multiple expansion, because earnings forecasts haven't kept pace.

BE11:26am

2017 PE gone from 20x to 75x over the same period.

BE11:27am

2018 from 15x to 60x!

11:26 am
BE11:27am

2019 up to 45x, from 20ish a year ago.

BE11:27am

Curious, right?

BE11:27am

Another thing to note, perhaps, is that Mahmud Kamani, the co-founder, is sitting on a 17.7 per cent stake.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The last time he took money off the table was when he sold 61m in 2015, when the share price was sub 40p.

BE11:27am

His brothers Jalal and Nurez have 13.6% and 6.8% respectively, I think, and seem never to have sold down post the IPO.

BE11:27am

Ditto Carol Kane, fellow co-founder, who's on 4.5%.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

That's a lot of insiders sitting tight.

BE11:28am

Meanwhile!

BE11:28am

As we know, Amazon's going headlong into own-label non-brand fashion, which has been a very successful niche for Boohoo.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

You'll remember the stories a week or so ago about Amazon hiring people from M&S and Primark.

BE11:28am

Coincidentally, there's one of those UBS Evidence Lab things out this morning about apparel Amazonifying.

BE11:29am

A trend led by Amazon itself in the US, but with Europe a bit more of a free-for-all.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here are two charts harvested from that:

BE11:29am

BE11:29am

And:

11:29 am
BE11:29am

BE11:29am

And ........ well, perhaps that's all we'll do on the Boohoo theme for now.

BE11:30am

I'm a wee bit mindful of PM's warning on Monday that, whenever a reporter lands a big story, their next one's inevitably a pup.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

So let's be clear. There's no story on Boohoo!

BE11:30am

(Yet.)

undefined
11:31 am
BE11:31am

ROTR having a wander round odd corporate names.

BE11:33am

I'm a fan of Big Bank Gdański. Sparkle Roll, the Chinese thing in Bang & Olufsen, is another quality bit of naming.

BE11:33am

But that's all a bit of subject. Where are we?

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Barclays requested, some time ago, so we can go there.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 240.20, up 5.05 (+2.15%), High: 244.40, Low: 238.35, Volume: 25.64m
BE11:35am

P&L misses consensus, but it's only because they're paying themselves too much.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

We're doing the usual sweep of the FTAV to see if this ML session is working.

BE11:36am

Here comes Jefferies to summarise.

BE11:36am

Barclays’s Q4 16 PBT was a 55% miss to consensus (see Exhibit
overleaf), though 7% ahead after adding back £395m of costs related to a “restructure of compensation awards”. Capital was stronger than expected at 12.4% vs. cons. of 11.8% on lower RWAs and a 20bps tailwind from the defined pension scheme deficit reduction. Core ROTE = 6.4% (9.4% for FY 15 ex notable items). Company guiding to £900m separation costs related to Africa, with a 75bps gain to CET1 from the regulatory deconsolidation of BAGL to come. Fixed income revenues grew 32% YoY, a result consistent with peers. International card impairments rose 53% YoY, and remain elevated for a second quarter. Non-core unit expected to close 6 months ahead with £25bn of RWAs. TNAV = 290p/share. Hard to see upgrades to consensus on the back of these results.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Capital stronger: CET1 12.4% v JEFe at 11.6% (RWAs totalled £366bn v JEFe at £373bn); this included a 20bps gain from the reduction in the defined pension scheme deficit. Pillar 2A
requirement is increasing 10bps in 2017, and BARC now targeting CET1 150-200bps above minimum regulatory level (vs. previous guidance of 100-150bps).
IB Revenues: Q4 FICC revenue in-line at £766m, up 32% YoY, driven by US flow business in credit and a strong rates performance. Equities +29% yoy, driven by strong cash and derivatives. Corporate lending revenues fell 3% on margin compression. The investment bank ROTE in 2016 was 7.3% ex the compensation and other charges. Nothing in the outlook statement as to how the IB has performed ytd.
Impairments: International card impairments rose 53% YoY, given balance growth of 24% and changes in the portfolio mix, coupled with FX movements. Barclaycard US 30 and 90 day delinquency rates have also increased to 2.6% in 2016 (FY15=2.2%) and 1.3% (FY15=1.1%). Impairments in the IB also rose 8% yoy driven by single name exposures. BARC notes underlying impairment trends in the UK are stable (echoing LLOY commentary) and are seeing improved delinquency rates in the UK cards portfolio.
Africa: BAGL de-consolidation will add 75bps to CET1, but BARC will incur £895m of changes to agree the separation, and are still awaiting regulatory approval to proceed with further sell-downs, so timing of CET1 gain remains uncertain.
Non-core: Non core to close 6 months early, with £25bn in RWAs. £1bn pbt loss guide for 2017 is in-line, and will be 1H front-loaded.
Valuation: Tangible book value up 3p/share to 290p/share, leaves the shares trading on 0.8x.

BE11:38am

Okay, so this compensation change is a one-off?

BE11:38am

Taking a £395m deferral charge ...... Hm.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Rather than try and understand the logic and moving parts of that myself, I'll sling up some Deutsche.

BE11:40am

he CET1 ratio printed at 12.4%, 60bps ahead of DBe and consensus in the quarter, despite the statutory miss on earnings, driven by lower RWAs (+30bps), pension movements (+20bps), currency translation reserve (+20bps). TNAV was also 3% ahead of DBe at 290p. Importantly, this puts Barclays within its target capital range (12.3-12.8%) today, and before the capital contribution of Africa (greater than 75bps capital accretion expected net of £868m TSA costs to come). Barclays has accelerated the run-down of non-core, with RWAs falling to £32bn at FY16, and will now close non-core 6 months ahead of schedule at 1H17. Non-core losses in 2017 are expected to be c.£1bn (ex- ESHLA, and front-loaded to 1H17) which is in line with current consensus.

BE11:41am

Markets revenues were a 1% beat vs. DBe, and total Barclays International income was a 2% beat vs. consensus. Within this credit was a 7% beat vs. DBe, macro a 10% miss, equities a 14% beat (across cash, derivatives and financing), and banking a 25% beat. Converting to US$ and comparing with other I-bank peers this was a weaker than expected performance for FICC (+9% YoY, vs US banks +43% and Europeans +15%, though in line with European peers on a QoQ basis), but stronger YoY for equities and banking.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The source of the impairment miss in the core bank was in Barclays International with overall impairments around £100m ahead of us and consensus (UK was in line). Company says this is driven by a rise in delinquency rates (90d up from 2.4% to 2.6% QoQ), balance growth, mix shift, & FX in Barclaycard US. CRL coverage rose 3% QoQ to 119% in International.

undefined
BE11:42am

Centrica (!) mentioned on the right.

11:41 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 226.40, down 7.3 (-3.12%), High: 229.80, Low: 223.70, Volume: 15.58m
BE11:42am

No divi.

BE11:42am

Because pensioners before shareholders. Which is fair enough, right?

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Though I guess there might be some overlap in the pensioner-shareholder ven.

BE11:44am

Who've we not quoted yet this morning? Credit Suisse? They'll do.

BE11:44am

Centrica this morning reported FYdec16 results. EPS was 16.8p (CS est. 16.7p, Guidance 16.5p). The results was cautious on 2017 owing to the pensions deficit—which is a big issue that has come to the fore—and the Rough storage costs. The dividend was therefore disappointing and Centrica basically is now flagging £2.5-3.0bn net debt (previously we believe the business supported £3.8bn).

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Comment
 Adjusted operating cash flow was £2.7bn, (CS est. c£2.5bn, Guidance c£2.4-2.6bn, PY c£2.25bn) of which c£0.4bn is due to working capital flow-back from billing system problems with BG Business.
Underlying was flat yoy. EBIT was £1,515m (CS est. £1,542m, PY £1,458m) and EPS was 16.8p (CS est. 16.7p, Thomson Reuters smart estimates consensus 16.5p).
 What is key is that the pension deficit has risen from £0.1bn one year ago to £1.1bn. This is a combination of lower long-term interest rates and inflation coming through. The company wants to get to £2.5-3.0bn adjusted net debt before growing the dividend (we think debt capacity was previously
£3.8bn), and Centrica expect to be there by the end of 2017. However, the DPS will not grow by inflation until then. This means the DPS was 12.0p (flat YOY, CS est. 12.5P) rather than growing at inflation. S&P have Centrica BBB+ (negative outlook).
 Centrica has taken c£384m of cost out of the business for the full year 2016, and aims to take out another £250m in 2017. We see this as easily achievable as the exit rate from 2016 (i.e. annualisation from December) is likely to be higher. However, the adjusted operating cash flow guidance of ‘exceeding £2bn’ (CS est. £2.4bn) appears low given this cost saving.
 The Rough storage business lost £52m in 2016A, and this is expected by the company to be higher in 2017E. The delays in completing caliper runs and pressure tests, and the resulting low levels of storage use and suspension of injection are likely to be the reasons.
 For FYdec17, we forecast £2.4bn of adjusted operating cash flow, driven by improvements in gas and oil production and a lack of warm weather impacting Direct Energy. At the EPS level, we forecast 17.8p (consensus 16.9p). We think it could be the first ‘up’ year since 2012. However, the company sounds more cautious and flags the higher pensions interest charge and the impact of the prepayment cap.

BE11:46am

(@Willosaurus: yes, sorry. I meant no increase. The day Centrica scraps its divi is one I'd imagine it'll be down rather more than 2%.)

BE11:46am

Centrica trades on a 2017E dividend yield of c5.6%, compared to the sub-sector on c4.9%. Our valuation and Outperform rating is driven by our SOTP, and we see the upside coming from cost-cutting in the gas and oil production business, and the fact we view GB domestic supply margins as stable. Nonetheless, the news on the pension deficit and dividend is disappointing.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Oh, and while on the sector ..........

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 350.00, up 2.2 (+0.63%), High: 355.30, Low: 348.80, Volume: 421.90k
BE11:47am

Having what we used to call in market reporting cliche bingo "a two way pull"

11:47 am
BE11:48am

First, there's a lively story in this morning's Times about biomass.

BE11:48am

http://www.thetime...rogramme-n7hf0h6ht

BE11:49am

First three paragraphs of that, because in terms of stories about infrastructure investment they're as good as three paragraphs get.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Britain is wasting hundreds of millions of pounds subsidising power stations to burn American wood pellets that do more harm to the climate than the coal they replaced, a study has found.

Chopping down trees and transporting wood across the Atlantic Ocean to feed power stations produces more greenhouse gases than much cheaper coal, according to the report. It blames the rush to meet EU renewable energy targets, which resulted in ministers making the false assumption that burning trees was carbon-neutral.

Green subsidies for wood pellets and other biomass were championed by Chris Huhne when he was Liberal Democrat energy and climate change secretary in the coalition government. Mr Huhne, 62, who was jailed in 2013 for perverting the course of justice, is now European chairman of Zilkha Biomass, a US supplier of wood pellets.

BE11:49am

Hm.

BE11:50am

The other bit of news re Drax is that yesterday, Rentech idled production at Wawa.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Wawa being a pellet factory in Canada.

BE11:50am

And Rentech being Drax's pellet supplier.

BE11:51am

And note that Rentech's a microcap. $30m. So production issues aren't something it can ride over too easily.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

According to Socgen, this is good news for Drax

BE11:52am

Rentech's problems are "a procurement opportunity"

BE11:52am

While Drax entered into a 10-year 400ktpa supply contract with Rentech in 2013, it received just 188ktpa of supply in 2016 (vs Drax’s 7mtpa of pellet consumption), and with its US$ hedge in place, we believe Drax should be able to secure alternative supplies at a lower cost than its £8/GJ guidance (we estimate current spot purchases equate to £6/GJ).

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Rentech’s Wawa facility could also present a cost-effective (less than $40m) way for Drax to increase its current 1mpta pellet manufacturing capacity, but this is not the only distressed pellet manufacturing facility currently being auctioned (we note the 120ktpa Scotia Biomass facility is being sold by receivers). In contrast to Drax’s recent Opus Energy and OCGT development acquisitions, to which we apply a degree of value dilution, we would view additional pellet investment as value accretive. Given the cash generation of the business, we think Drax could combine an attractive dividend policy with pellet investments – our DPS forecasts assume Drax will return only around half of its surplus cash generation of c. £200m. On this basis the DY increases to 7.8% by 2019e.

BE11:54am

Ashley Thomas is the analyst there.

undefined
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Still picking up on ROTR stuff ..... was RSA mentioned earlier?

RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 615.50, up 38.5 (+6.67%), High: 615.50, Low: 590.50, Volume: 4.41m
BE11:55am

Cost targets raised, operating earnings ahead.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Imagine if shareholders had taken the 525p Zurich were offering?

BE11:57am

And remind me, who helped collapse that dea.... oh, it was me. Of course. Anyway.

BE11:57am

Here's Barclays on RSA's numbers.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

We upgraded RSA to Overweight in our note “Ambitious or over ambitious” (3 May 2016) on the thesis that the company had a realistic plan to get towards its 2018 ambitions. The FY16 results show the company is making significant progress to its ambitions, with operating earnings increasing 25% YoY to £655m, 5% above company-collected consensus. This is driven primarily by the underlying underwriting result increasing 60% to £392m (+5% ahead of consensus), with a core combined ratio of 93.8% (220bps YoY improvement). This was a high quality beat – large losses and weather losses marginally increased YoY – the improvement was driven by a 140bps improvement in the underlying (attritional) loss ratio and 50bps improvement in expense ratio.

BE11:58am

Cost saves target increased by £50m (equivalent to 7% of PBT) and ROTE targets increased

The company has increased its cost save target for a third time from in excess of £350m to in excess of £400m by 2018. An incremental £50m of cost saves is equivalent to c7% of our previously published FY18 estimates. The company also increased its return on tangible equity (ROTE) objective from a previous 12-15% to a new range of 13-17%, primarily due to the recently announced sale of its legacy business. ROTE was 14.2% in FY16, and a 17% ROTE on the FY16 tangible equity f £2.9bn or 281p per share would be equivalent to 47.7p per share. A 17% ROTE on our previously published FY18 tangible book value per share estimate of 321p would be equivalent to a 54.6p per share.

Solvency capital in line at 158% (top end of range) - legacy sale will add 17 to 20 points

RSA’s Solvency capital was in line with our expectations at 158%, at the top end of its 130-160% range. As the company disclosed earlier in the month, the sale of legacy will add an additional 17-20 points to its Solvency 2 ratio, equivalent to £300-350m of capital. As we discussed in our note “RSA - Legacy sales accretive to Sol 2 and EPS” (8 Feb 2017), we believe the company will use this excess capital to pay down its expensive debt, which could increase FY18 earnings estimates by c3.5%. This is not in our estimates as it depends on which debt the company decides to pay down. The company has confirmed that this is what it intends to do with the excess capital.

Full-year dividend increased by 52% to 16.0p, 5% ahead of consensus and equivalent to a 41% payout.

RSA increased the dividend by 52% to 16.0p, 5% ahead of consensus estimates and equivalent to a 2.7% yield and a 41% payout. The company has reiterated that its medium-term policy is for an ordinary dividend of 40-50%, with additional payouts (specials) where justified. The company has also stated that the additional payouts should follow the completion of restructuring and progress in the unwind of unrealized bond gains. With limited top-line growth, we expect the company to start to pay regular special dividends by 2018 – 62.5% payout in 2018 (when the restructuring is complete) and 75% payout from 2019 onwards when the unrealized bond unwind is largely done.

BE11:58am

And JP Morgan.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

RSA has this morning reported strong FY16 results. Underlying PBT of £556m is 6% ahead JPMe at £526m, and underlying EPS of 39.5p is 9% ahead of JPMe and company consensus 36.4p. The outperformance is due to a combination of higher than expected premiums (partially due to FX we believe), and a stronger investment result. The combined ratio is exactly inline with our estimate and consensus at 94.2%, while Solvency at 158% is slightly below the 160% we had assumed. RSA has today increased its cost efficiency target to greater than £400m by 2015 (was greater than £350m), and increased its medium term ROTE guidance to 13-17% (was 12-15%). Based on our TNAV estimates we note that this is equivalent to EPS in the range of 41.3p-54.1p, which compares to FY18 consensus at 50p. Overall a strong FY16 result in our view, which may result in some modest upside risk to FY18 consensus.

undefined
BE11:59am

Purplebricks? Sure.

11:59 am
Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 265.00, up 39 (+17.26%), High: 269.25, Low: 245.00, Volume: 1.35m
BE11:59am

Now valued at nearly £700m, I think.

BE12:00pm

Still to print any kind of profit, and is on about 90x 2018.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

But ... hey, disruption. Gig economy. Whatever.

BE12:01pm

News today is they've sold 22.7m shares as 220p apiece

BE12:01pm

To roll the business out to the US.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

That's a £50m raise.

BE12:02pm

Now, doesn't the US realty market already work in a slightly more hybrid fashion to the UK estate agent market?

BE12:03pm

I'm basing that claim a bit on that episode of the Simpsons where Marge becomes a realtor, admittedly. It might need more research.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

BE12:05pm

............ anyway, no sellside on the move I've seen. So, that's about it for insights there. Once again I recommend Anthony Codling of Jefferies if you want a deep and quite contrarian view of the Purplebricks operating model.

undefined
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

.... look at the time!

BE12:05pm

Didn't mention AO World.

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 146.60, down 5 (-3.30%), High: 149.00, Low: 145.50, Volume: 162.07k
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

... and the orderly succession by which its founder has been sidelined, announced post close yesterday.

BE12:06pm

"Natural progression," Numis says.

BE12:07pm

We expect little difference in the day-to-day roles undertaken by the team and, as much as anything, see these changes as a recognition that AO's senior management roles have evolved over time. Regardless of these changes, we retain our positive stance on AO, with the business back on the front foot in the UK and set to replicate its outstanding customer-led proposition in Germany and beyond.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

... while Shore, without worrying overly about Mr Robers' departure, gives the business model another kick.

BE12:08pm

Whilst this is the case it was and remains our view that AO was mispriced at flotation and many long standing original shareholders have endured material capital erosion after the initial post IPO price spike. Valuation aside, that erosion reflects not the aforementioned operational achievements of running and expanding the offer and reach the business but a steady and sustained erosion of EBITDA expectations, a process that we still do not know whether or not it has ran its full course despite our own efforts to set cautious and/or achievable financial targets for the business.

BE12:09pm

As such whilst the capabilities and strategic potential of AO are undeniable to us and there appears to be proprietary value within the business, there is also a difficulty in our minds understanding what base profitability is going to be, where it can go to in the medium to long-term and at what pace? For these reasons we believe that whilst some patient investors remain firmly loyal to and evangelise the AO investment cause many more others are prepared to wait and watch for greater evidence of financial stability, delivery and a clearer trajectory before investing in the group's shares.

12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

That's a small section of Clive's note. He's a holder, and he certainly shows his working.

undefined
BE12:10pm

So, thanks for keeping me company this past 70 minutes.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Until tomorrow, afternoon all.

BE11:35am

CET1 print's pretty reassuring.
